text: when turkey comes out you want to let it
sit absorb back all that great juice the
way you know it's sat long enough and
it's cooled enough is that you'll be
able to use your hand when you're
carving it and not have to use a fork to
pierce it we're more that natural juices
will come spilling and pouring out of
the meat with just a 5 to 6 inch knife
we're going to start with the back legs
to open up the back so the breastbone
will start cooling from underneath which
will make the breast peel off easier
when we get to it you're going to take
your hand and just start pushing to the
side towards towards your cutting board
and with just that top inch of the knife
in between where the leg and the body
meet you're just gonna slice right
through this is called scoring it it
breaks the membrane so that the meat
will peel right off the joint that
connects the leg and the body is right
there the joint will pop open and that's
where you'll be able to go through with
your knife and you're just gonna cut
straight down to your cutting board and
remove the leg then once you have the
leg off in the V of shape of the leg is
where the drumstick and the thigh are
connected with just your knife in that
space you're just going to open up the
next joint cut it straight through to
your block I like to take my drum put it
on my end of my platter then you have a
full piece of meat a thigh the thigh
bone will come out easy you take just
the point of the knife again and you're
just going to open up and run it along
the bone on both sides once you can see
the bone then you can grab one end of it
and with the point of your knife run the
point along the bone and twist the bone
at the same time and the bone will
literally roll right out of the turkey
now you take your bigger knife a 10 to
12 inch knife is fine remove your skin
because your knife will not slice
through the skin and it'll dull your
blade and you'll be able to make nice
solid slices of thigh meat which makes
it go a lot faster when you slice nice
big pieces then I like to take the dark
meat put it right on the end in my
platter where then I'll put the drum on
the other side so that the dark meat is
all together for whoever wants it now
that we have the drum and thigh out of
the way we're going to go to the wing
next what I like to do with that is to
just pull it open a little bit and again
you see a v-shape again that's where the
joint is connected and that's where
you'll be able to separate it then I
like to leave the drum at section on
what this will do is when we go to do
our breast meat this will give you
better stability
okay now we're gonna start on our
breasts as I've said before the skin
especially get a nice crisp brown skin
I'm not gonna be able to cut through
with your knife and it'll dull the edge
of your knife so you are better off just
peel the skin back now the bone has a
curve to it so what you want to do is
start to pull lightly with your hand and
with the point of your knife just keep
following along the curve of the bone
and the breast will roll right off and
you have the solid piece of breast that
you let to continue cool while you do
the other side and then we'll slice now
nice and flat on our cutting board we're
going to take our long steak knife now
we can see that the lines of the meat
are running just like that against the
grain which be against those lines
that's where we want to cut wanted two
key things about your bout your breast
meat to keep it nice and juicy and
flavorful is you don't want to cut it
too thin to where it'll dry out as you
walk across the room with the platter so
you want it to be 1/8 of an inch to a
quarter of an inch thick and that is how
I would serve it on my table
